Chief Complaint: OUTPATIENT CARDIOLOGIST:  Dr [**Last Name (STitle) **], [**Location (un) 2408**]
   Cardiology
   .
   PCP:[**Name10 (NameIs) **] [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Name (STitle) 13964**]
   .
   CHIEF COMPLAINT: respiratory distress
   24 Hour Events:
 EKG - At [**2109-2-2**] 09:40 AM
 OR SENT - At [**2109-2-2**] 11:22 AM
 ARTERIAL LINE - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:47 PM
 OR RECEIVED - At [**2109-2-2**] 01:47 PM
 MULTI LUMEN - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:48 PM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - START [**2109-2-2**] 01:50 PM
 INVASIVE VENTILATION - STOP [**2109-2-2**] 04:00 PM
   .
   HISTORY OF PRESENTING ILLNESS:72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG (6), systolic
   CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus admitted,
   sleep apnea on BIPAP to SICU from OSH([**Location (un) 2408**]) with confusion s/p fall
   found on Head CT to have subdural hematoma s/p evacuation/burr hole. On
   arrival was in afib managed with IV metoprolol given NPO and on BIPAP
   s/p extubation post burrhole/evacuation. Cards consult for assitance
   with cardiac management given hx, with assessment that there was no
   evidence CHF/active ischemia and to continue cards meds (plavix/asa
   were being held given head bleed. Had been holding his lasix and
   antihtn's (lisinopril 10, carvedilol 12.5) and pt received 3L IV fluids
   in OR. Overnight became more tachypneic with poor UOP received 10mg IV
   lasix an [**9-5**] 9am then another 20mg IV with only small increase in UOP
   but hypotensive to mid 80s with boluses. Noted by cards on f/u to be
   clinically volume overload consistent with CVP of 24 with Bedside Echo
   poor quality but showed Afib, stable severe LV dilation with EF 15%,
   elevated LA pressure, 1 + MR with no priors for comparison. Initial CXR
   on admission showed pulmonary congestion, repeat CXR at this point did
   not show any change. Also noted to have worsening Cr from 1.3 on
   admission to 1.9 currently. He was at this point admitted to CCU
   service for management heart failure.
   .
   On transfer to cards he was +ve 1500cc for the day with CVP 24.
   Switched to lasix gtt, with goal UOP 100-150cc/hr. He restarted his
   carvedilol although lisinopril was held given his renal failure.
   .
   On review of systems,per daughter pt had "platelet allergy in
   ambulance, hx unclear. he denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep
   venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery,
   myalgias, joint pains, cough, hemoptysis, black stools or red stools.he
   denies recent fevers, chills or rigors. S/he denies exertional buttock
   or calf pain. All of the other review of systems were negative.
   .
   Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea
   on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema,
   palpitations, syncope or presyncope.
   .
   PAST MEDICAL HISTORY: DM, CAD s/p MI, CABG, Afib, CHF w/ EF 15% s/p
   ICD, sleep apnea on BIPAP
   Cardiac Risk Factors include diabetes, CAD.
   .
   HOME MEDICATIONS: ASA 81 mg, Carvedilol 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **], Lisinopril 10 mg
   daily, Plavix 75 mg daily, Lasix 40 mg [**Hospital1 **], Zocor 40 mg q day, KCl 20
   meq daily, Prilosec 20 mg daily, MVI, Insulin Novolog 70/30
   .
   Meds on transfer:
   Furosemide 1-5 mg/hr IV DRIP INFUSION
   titrate to net NEGATIVE 50-100cc per hour
   Heparin 5000 UNIT SC TID
   Clopidogrel 75 mg PO/NG DAILY
   Phenytoin Sodium Extended 100 mg PO TID
   Ondansetron 4 mg IV Q8H:PRN nausea
   HydrALAzine 10 mg IV Q6H SBP>160
   Acetaminophen 325-650 mg PO/NG Q6H:PRN fever/pain
   Senna 1 TAB PO/NG [**Hospital1 7**]
   Docusate Sodium 100 mg PO BID
   Simvastatin 40 mg PO/NG DAILY  [**2-2**] @ 1138 View
   Omeprazole 20 mg PO DAILY
   Carvedilol 12.5 mg PO/NG [**Hospital1 7**]
   .
   ALLERGIES: NKDA
   SOCIAL HISTORY: Retired, lives with wife. In dependant of ADLs. Smoker
   in past.
   .
   FAMILY HISTORY: Noncontributory for CAD
   . .
   LABS/STUDIEs:
   TELEMETRY: AF intermittenly paced
   ECG [**2109-2-2**]: AF with intermitted ventricular pacing. LBBB in native
   beats.
   Head CT:
   1. Large lentiform predominantly hypodense extra-axial collection along
   the left cerebral hemisphere, with hyperdense rim and internal
   septations, compatible with chronic subdural hematoma. This collection
   causes substantial mass effect, including rightward subfalcine
   herniation and early left uncal herniation. Findings not changed from
   one day prior.
   2. Hypodense evolving subacute posterior right temporal lobe infarct,
   in the territory of the right MCA, unchanged.
   .
   CXR: A dual-lead pacemaker generator overlies the left upper
   hemithorax, with leads terminating in the right atrium and right
   ventricle. Median sternotomy wires are in place. Lung volumes are low.
   Bilaterally, there is perihilar vascular congestion. The heart is
   enlarged. There may be a trace right effusion, but there is no left
   pleural effusion or consolidation. There is no pneumothorax.
   IMPRESSION: Cardiomegaly and pulmonary congestion.
   .
   2D-ECHOCARDIOGRAM:  [**2109-2-3**]
   The left atrium is elongated. The right atrium is moderately dilated.
   Left ventricular wall thicknesses are normal. The left ventricular
   cavity is severely dilated. Due to suboptimal technical quality, a
   focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully excluded. Overall left
   ventricular systolic function is severely depressed (LVEF= 15 %). The
   right ventricular cavity is moderately dilated with mild global free
   wall hypokinesis. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The aortic
   valve leaflets (3) are mildly thickened. No aortic regurgitation is
   seen. The mitral valve leaflets are moderately thickened. Mild (1+)
   mitral regurgitation is seen. [Due to acoustic shadowing, the severity
   of mitral regurgitation may be significantly UNDERestimated.] The left
   ventricular inflow pattern suggests a restrictive filling abnormality,
   with elevated left atrial pressure. There is a very small pericardial
   effusion.
   .
   LABORATORY DATA:
   See below.
   Allergies:
   No Known Drug Allergies
   Last dose of Antibiotics:

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)

   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: 72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG (6), systolic CHF (EF

   If unable to tolerate BP wise consider milrinone for ionotrope assisted

   Continue diuresis with lasix
   check 9pm electrolytes
   Continue to trend Cr.
   Consider renal consult if not improving in am.
   .
   # subdural hematoma s/p burrhole/evacuation.
   Per daughter [**Name (NI) 13965**] in am, sundowns
   -serial neuro checks
   -avoid benzo's, frequent reorientation
   restarting ASA/plavix in am
   appreciate neuro recs.
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: CPAP o/n
   .
   COMM: Wife: [**Name (NI) **] [**Name (NI) 13966**]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 13967**].
   .

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of CAD, MI, CABG, CHF, and atrial fibrillation, who was admitted to the ICU after a fall and subsequent evacuation of a subdural hematoma. He was found to have severe LV dilation with an EF of 15%, elevated LA pressure, and 1+ MR. He was also noted to have worsening Cr from 1.3 to 1.9. He was started on IV diuresis with lasix and was transferred to the cardiology service.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Volume Overload: The patient's IV infusion of lasix was increased to 10 mg/hr, but he is still positive 1500cc on transfer to cards. He is at risk for further volume overload, which could lead to pulmonary edema and worsening cardiac function.
2. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's Cr has increased from 1.3 to 1.9, and his FENA is 0.8, consistent with prerenal failure from poor forward flow. He is at risk for further renal deterioration and may require renal consult.
3. Cardiac Failure: The patient's EF is severely depressed, and he has evidence of pulmonary congestion on CXR. He is at risk for further cardiac decompensation and may require inotrope therapy.
4. Subdural Hematoma: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma and is at risk for further bleeding, particularly with anticoagulation therapy.
5. Sleep Apnea: The patient has sleep apnea and is at risk for further respiratory compromise, particularly with the use of BIPAP.
6. Infections: The patient is at risk for infections, particularly with the use of central lines and the presence of a subdural hematoma.
7. Thromboembolic Events: The patient is at risk for thromboembolic events, particularly with the use of anticoagulation therapy and the presence of a subdural hematoma.

Recommendations:

1. Continue IV diuresis with lasix to manage volume overload.
2. Monitor the patient's Cr levels and consider renal consult if not improving.
3. Consider inotrope therapy to manage cardiac failure.
4. Monitor the patient's subdural hematoma and consider further imaging studies if there is any concern for further bleeding.
5. Continue to manage the patient's sleep apnea with BIPAP.
6. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and consider antibiotics if necessary.
7. Consider thromboprophylaxis with heparin or warfarin to reduce the risk of thromboembolic events.

Note: The patient's history of CAD, MI, and CABG places him at high risk for cardiac events, and his current cardiac function is severely depressed. The patient's subdural hematoma and sleep apnea also increase his risk for further complications. Close monitoring and aggressive management of these conditions will be necessary to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He has a subdural hematoma (SDH) with a burr hole/evacuation, atrial fibrillation (Afib), and systolic heart failure (EF 15%). He was admitted to the ICU with respiratory failure and was started on bipap. He had an increase in central nervous system (CNS) pressure, which led to apneic episodes and tachypnea. His blood pressure (BP) was elevated, and his heart rate (HR) was irregularly irregular. His oxygen saturation (SpO2) was 96%. His laboratory results showed a white blood cell count (WBC) of 16.7, hemoglobin (Hb) of 13.9 g/dL, and creatinine (Cr) of 1.9 mg/dL.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Volume Overload: The patient's volume overload is likely due to his Afib and poor forward flow, which can lead to further cardiac compromise and respiratory failure.
2. Renal Failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure may worsen if not managed properly, leading to electrolyte imbalances and further cardiac compromise.
3. Sleep Apnea: The patient's sleep apnea can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further respiratory failure and cardiac compromise.
4. Subdural Hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further neurological compromise and potential brain herniation.
5. Cardiac Compromise: The patient's cardiac compromise can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further cardiac failure and potential cardiac arrest.
6. Electrolyte Imbalances: The patient's electrolyte imbalances can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential cardiac arrest.
7. Infection: The patient's increased WBC count may indicate an underlying infection, which can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further cardiac compromise and potential sepsis.

Recommendations:

1. Continue diuresis with lasix to manage volume overload and renal failure.
2. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medication regimen as needed.
3. Continue to manage his sleep apnea with CPAP.
4. Monitor the patient's subdural hematoma and neurological status closely.
5. Continue to manage his cardiac compromise with medications and consider invasive cardiac monitoring.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust his bipap settings as needed.
7. Consider consulting a renal specialist to optimize the patient's renal function.
8. Consider consulting a neurosurgeon to manage the patient's subdural hematoma.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac rhythm and adjust his medication regimen as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD), previous myocardial infarction (MI), and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He has also had a subdural hematoma with burr hole/evacuation, atrial fibrillation (Afib), and chronic systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction (EF) of 15%.

The patient has been admitted to the ICU with worsening respiratory status, becoming increasingly short of breath (SOB) and requiring a face mask for bipap. He has also had apneic episodes, tachypnea, and grunting, with a carbon dioxide (CO2) level of 50 mmHg. The patient's electrocardiogram (EKG) shows new twinning (TWI) in V1 to V5, which is concerning for central process, possibly related to the subdural hematoma or pulmonary embolism (PE).

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count (WBC) of 16.7 K/uL, which is trending down from 19.8 K/uL. His hemoglobin (Hb) is 13.9 g/dL, and his platelet count (Plt) is 44.3%. His creatinine (Cr) level is 1.9 mg/dL, and his blood urea nitrogen (BUN) is 34 mg/dL.

The patient's medical conditions include subdural hematoma, atrial fibrillation, chronic systolic CHF, and sleep apnea. He is currently on medications for these conditions, including carvedilol, simvastatin, and warfarin.

The patient's plan includes continuing diuresis with lasix, weaning bipap, and monitoring his oxygen saturation (SpO2) levels. He will also have his electrolytes checked daily, and his creatinine level will be trended. The patient's subdural hematoma will be followed up with serial neuro checks, and he will be restarted on aspirin and plavix in the morning.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's worsening respiratory status and apneic episodes put him at risk for respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's atrial fibrillation and new TWI on his EKG put him at risk for cardiac arrhythmias, including ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
3. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC count and possible central process put him at risk for sepsis.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease put him at risk for renal failure.
5. Bleeding: The patient's subdural hematoma and possible coagulopathy put him at risk for bleeding.
6. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE risk factors, including his atrial fibrillation and immobility, put him at risk for pulmonary embolism.
7. Infection: The patient's immunocompromised state and possible central process put him at risk for infection.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a critically ill individual in the ICU with a complex medical history and multiple ongoing medical issues.

The patient's current condition is marked by:

1. Respiratory distress, with apneic episodes and tachypnea, requiring bipap support.
2. Cardiac instability, with new twave inversion in V1-V5 on EKG, possibly related to V pacing.
3. Central nervous system (CNS) involvement, with a subdural hematoma (SDH) and potential central sleep apnea.
4. Hematological abnormalities, including a subtherapeutic phenytoin level and a rising white blood cell count.
5. Cardiovascular instability, with a possible pulmonary embolism (PE) and a history of coronary artery disease (CAD).
6. Renal dysfunction, with an elevated creatinine level.
7. Metabolic derangements, including hyperglycemia and lactic acidosis.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: Prolonged apneic episodes can lead to respiratory failure and potentially fatal consequences.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The new twave inversion on EKG and V pacing may increase the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia.
3. Increased intracranial pressure: The subdural hematoma (SDH) may worsen, leading to increased intracranial pressure, brain herniation, and potentially fatal consequences.
4. Sepsis: The rising white blood cell count and potential bacteremia from the subdural hematoma (SDH) may lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
5. Renal failure: The elevated creatinine level may worsen, leading to acute kidney injury (AKI) and potentially fatal consequences.
6. Metabolic acidosis: The lactic acidosis and hyperglycemia may worsen, leading to metabolic acidosis and potentially fatal consequences.

In light of these findings, it is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust treatment accordingly to prevent potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 72-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrhythmia. He has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He has also had a subdural hematoma evacuated and is currently experiencing atrial fibrillation (Afib) with poor forward flow.

Over the past 24 hours, the patient has experienced worsening dyspnea and agitation, which was initially managed with lasix and diuril. However, his symptoms persisted, and he was found to have a CVP of 16-18 mmHg and a tachycardic heart rate. An EKG showed no significant changes, and the patient was started on a lasix bolus and given 500 mg of IV diuril.

The patient's lab results show:

* Hemoglobin: 14.1 g/dL
* Hematocrit: 41.4%
* White blood cell count: 19.8 K/uL
* Platelet count: 66 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's fluid balance shows:

* Total input: 1,023 mL
* Total output: 3,306 mL
* Balance: -2,283 mL

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.5°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (94-125 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/67 mmHg (72-123/92 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 34 inspirations per minute
* SpO2: 95%

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Volume overload: The patient's fluid balance is significantly positive, which can lead to volume overload and cardiac failure.
2. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has acute on chronic renal failure, which can worsen if not managed properly.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which can lead to further cardiac complications if not managed properly.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory rate is elevated, and he is on a bipap mask, which can lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to his compromised immune system and the presence of central lines and drains.
6. Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding complications, and his platelet count is low, which can increase his risk of bleeding.
7. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma and is at risk for further neurological complications.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent further complications.

Summary:

The patient, a 72-year-old male, is a post-cardiac arrest patient with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery. He has atrial fibrillation, systolic heart failure, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted to the ICU for volume overload and was treated with lasix, diuril, and heparin. He experienced increased agitation, tachypnea, and tachycardia overnight, which was managed with increased lasix and diuril. He is currently being treated with lasix, diuril, and carvedilol, and is receiving prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis and stress ulcer.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's CVP is elevated, and he is at risk for further fluid overload, which can exacerbate his heart failure and kidney disease.
2. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is contributing to his symptoms, and he is at risk for further cardiac complications.
3. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine levels are increasing, and he is at risk for further kidney damage.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 95%, but he is at risk for further respiratory decline due to his chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.
5. Infection: The patient has a central line and is at risk for central line-associated bloodstream infection.
6. Neurological decline: The patient has a history of sundowning and is at risk for further neurological decline.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient is at risk for gastrointestinal bleeding due to his anticoagulation therapy and his history of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's CVP and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
2. Continue to manage his atrial fibrillation with carvedilol and consider anticoagulation therapy.
3. Monitor his creatinine levels and adjust his diuretic therapy accordingly.
4. Monitor his oxygen saturation and adjust his respiratory therapy accordingly.
5. Continue to monitor his central line and consider removing it if not necessary.
6. Monitor his neurological status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
7. Monitor his gastrointestinal status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy accordingly.

The patient is a 24-hour-old post-operative patient in the ICU, with a cardiac history and undergoing cardiac surgery. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a Tmax of 36.4°C, Tcurrent of 36.1°C, HR of 98 bpm, BP of 89/67 mmHg, and SpO2 of 95%. The patient is receiving various medications, including lasix, diuril, and heparin, and has been given a bolus of diuril. The patient's lab results show elevated WBC, Cr, and TropT, and decreased Hct and Plt.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's dyspnea and agitation may indicate respiratory failure, which could worsen if not addressed.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's EKG shows possible AFib with intermittent V-pacing, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and further complications.
3. Fluid overload: The patient's CVP is elevated, which may indicate fluid overload, which could lead to respiratory and cardiac complications.
4. Sepsis: The patient's elevated WBC and TropT may indicate sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
5. Bleeding: The patient's decreased Plt and elevated Cr may indicate bleeding, which could lead to hemorrhagic complications.
6. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's lab results show electrolyte imbalance, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.
7. Infection: The patient's elevated WBC and TropT may indicate infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.
8. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's cardiac history and post-operative state may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as heart failure, MI, and arrhythmias.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac surgery (CABG). He has atrial fibrillation, systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15%, and is currently experiencing volume overload.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.5°F)
* Heart rate: 98 bpm (94-125 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 89/67 mmHg (72-123/92 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 34 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%
* Central venous pressure: 9 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 19.8 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 41.4%
* Platelet count: 66 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.0 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.2 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.2 mg/dL

The patient's medications include:

* Omeprazole (Prilosec)
* Furosemide (Lasix)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Dextrose 50%
* Plavix
* Keppra
* Dilantin
* Simvastatin
* Carvedilol
* Aspirin

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Diuresis with furosemide (Lasix)
* Monitoring of blood pressure, oxygen saturation, and central venous pressure
* Weaning of BIPAP
* Restarting of ASA and Plavix in the morning
* Continue carvedilol 12.5 mg
* Continue simvastatin 40 mg
* Restarting of ASA and Plavix in the morning
* Serial neuro checks
* Avoidance of benzodiazepines
* Frequent reorientation

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Volume overload: The patient is at risk of developing volume overload due to his atrial fibrillation and poor forward flow. This can lead to increased blood pressure, decreased cardiac output, and increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias.
* Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and he has a history of chronic renal failure. This can lead to further deterioration of his kidney function and increased risk of complications such as acute kidney injury.
* Respiratory failure: The patient's oxygen saturation is 95%, and he is receiving BIPAP. He may be at risk of developing respiratory failure if his oxygenation worsens or if he develops further respiratory complications.
* Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient has atrial fibrillation and is at risk of developing further cardiac arrhythmias, such as ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.
* Neurological complications: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma and is at risk of developing further neurological complications, such as intracranial hemorrhage or seizures.

Based on the patient's condition, it is essential to continue monitoring his vital signs, laboratory results, and medication regimen closely to prevent and manage potential complications.

Based on the physician resident progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and coronary artery bypass grafting. He has systolic heart failure with an ejection fraction of 15% and an implanted cardioverter-defibrillator. He also has atrial fibrillation and a subdural hematoma with a burr hole and evacuation.

The patient was noted to be more agitated, tachypneic, and decreasing urine output at 12:00 pm, which was treated with lasix gtt and chlorthiazide 500 mg IV x 1. He pulled at his central line and dislodged one stitch at 10:00 pm, which was confirmed by a chest X-ray showing the line in the superior vena cava.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 99 bpm (89-107 bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/81 mmHg (89-120/88 mmHg)
* Respiratory rate: 38 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 74%
* Heart rhythm: Ventricular paced
* Central venous pressure: 15 mmHg (6-20 mmHg)

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 16.7 K/uL
* Hematocrit: 48.3%
* Platelet count: 293 K/uL
* Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04 ng/mL
* Glucose: 100 mg/dL

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue lasix gtt with a goal urine output of 50-100 cc/hr
* Monitor central venous pressure
* Continue to trend creatinine
* [Hospital1 7] lytes during diuresis
* Increase carvedilol to 25 mg [Hospital1 7]
* Discuss Coumadin with outpt cardiologist and neuro sx
* Continue simvastatin, carvedilol
* Restart ASA when ok with neuro sx
* Continue diuresis
* Continue to monitor neuro status
* Neuro checks q4 hrs
* Appreciate neuro sx input

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the patient's condition include:

* Cardiac complications: atrial fibrillation, cardiac failure, and coronary artery disease
* Respiratory complications: acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), pneumonia, and respiratory failure
* Renal complications: acute kidney injury, chronic kidney disease, and electrolyte imbalance
* Neurological complications: subdural hematoma, brain edema, and seizures
* Infection complications: sepsis, pneumonia, and catheter-related infections

It is essential to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust the plan of care accordingly to prevent these potential complications from occurring.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) after myocardial infarction (MI) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic congestive heart failure (CHF) with an ejection fraction of 15%, and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He also has atrial fibrillation and a subdural hematoma with burr hole evacuation.

The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with increased agitation, tachypnea, and decreasing urine output. His vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.8°F)
* Heart rate: 99 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 110/81 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 38 inspirations per minute (ins/min)
* Oxygen saturation: 74%
* Central venous pressure: 15 mmHg

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 16.7
* Hematocrit: 48.3%
* Platelet count: 293
* Creatinine: 1.6 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.04
* Lactic acid: 1.9 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* Calcium: 9.2 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.3 mg/dL
* Phosphate: 3.4 mg/dL

The patient's condition is complicated by:

1. CHF/Fluid Overload: The patient is volume overloaded, requiring further diuresis.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's tachycardia is likely contributing to his symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
3. Coronaries: The patient has CAD s/p CABG, and his coronary arteries are not significantly diseased.
4. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is 1.6 mg/dL, above his recent baseline of 1.2 mg/dL, likely due to prerenal failure.
5. DM: The patient's fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
6. Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: The patient's neurologic exam is stable, but he requires further neurologic monitoring.
7. Sleep Apnea: The patient is being treated with BiPAP overnight and when napping.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continue lasix gtt to achieve an I + O negative 2 L today.
2. Change carvedilol to metoprolol for rate control with less antihypertensive effect and uptitrate as needed.
3. No Coumadin for now, but may consider it in 3 weeks after neurosurgical follow-up.
4. Continue simvastatin and aspirin (if okay from neurosurgical perspective).
5. Continue diuresis and trend creatinine.
6. Continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose.
7. Repeat head CT this a.m.
8. Remove central line today.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of CHF/Fluid Overload, leading to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.
2. Atrial Fibrillation exacerbating the patient's symptoms, leading to poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure, leading to worsening kidney function and potential need for dialysis.
4. Hypoglycemia, requiring increased insulin dosing.
5. Neurological complications from the subdural hematoma, such as increased intracranial pressure and seizures.
6. Sleep Apnea exacerbating the patient's respiratory symptoms, leading to respiratory failure and cardiac arrest.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent these potential complications and improve his overall outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old woman with a history of CAD, DM, HTN, and CVA who presented for ASA desensitization prior to catheterization. She has acute renal failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and subdural hemorrhage. Her laboratory results show elevated creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and potassium levels, as well as anemia. She has been receiving prehydration, mucomyst, and lasix, and has had a successful ASA desensitization. Her medications include furosemide, morphine, heparin, metoprolol, and dilantin.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and she has been experiencing nephrotic syndrome. She may be at risk for further renal damage and may require dialysis.
2. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's restrictive cardiomyopathy may worsen, leading to heart failure and arrhythmias.
3. Subdural hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage may continue to expand, leading to increased intracranial pressure and potential brain herniation.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia may worsen, leading to fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection due to her catheterization and the presence of foreign bodies.
7. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for bleeding due to her subdural hemorrhage and the use of anticoagulant medications.
8. Respiratory failure: The patient's restrictive cardiomyopathy and potential respiratory failure may lead to respiratory distress and the need for mechanical ventilation.
9. Neurological complications: The patient's subdural hemorrhage and potential brain herniation may lead to neurological complications such as seizures, paralysis, and cognitive impairment.

Recommendations:

1. Monitor the patient's renal function closely and adjust her medications as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac function and adjust her medications as needed.
3. Monitor the patient's subdural hemorrhage and potential brain herniation, and consider surgical intervention if necessary.
4. Monitor the patient's anemia and adjust her medications as needed.
5. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her medications as needed.
6. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and take prompt action if infection is suspected.
7. Monitor the patient for signs of bleeding and take prompt action if bleeding is suspected.
8. Monitor the patient for signs of respiratory failure and take prompt action if respiratory failure is suspected.
9. Monitor the patient for signs of neurological complications and take prompt action if neurological complications are suspected.

Summary:

The patient is a 65-year-old woman with a history of CAD, DM, HTN, and CVA, who was admitted for ASA desensitization prior to a catheterization procedure. The patient developed contrast-induced nephropathy with a creatinine level of 1.88, which led to the deferral of the catheterization procedure. The patient was also found to have acute renal failure, restrictive cardiomyopathy, and a subdural hemorrhage.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.5°C
* Heart rate: 86 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 99/67 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 31 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 95%

The patient's physical examination revealed:

* General: Oriented x3, PERRLA, CN II-XII intact, 2-25 muscle strength
* Cardiac: Distant heart sounds, no murmurs or gallops
* Lungs: Clear to auscultation, no wheezes or rhonchi
* Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no masses or bruits
* Extremities: 2+ pitting edema to below the knee bilaterally

The patient's laboratory results include:

* Creatinine: 1.9 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 14.1 mg/dL
* Sodium: 113 mg/dL
* Potassium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Chloride: 29 mEq/L
* Bicarbonate: 4.4 mEq/L
* Glucose: 43 mg/dL

Potential medical complications:

1. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level of 1.9 mg/dL indicates acute renal failure, which may require further management and treatment.
2. Contrast-induced nephropathy: The patient's history of contrast-induced nephropathy may increase the risk of further kidney damage.
3. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: The patient's echocardiogram revealed diastolic CHF, EF 55%, LVH, and pulmonary HTN, which may indicate restrictive cardiomyopathy.
4. Subdural hemorrhage: The patient's subdural hemorrhage may require further evaluation and treatment.
5. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension may require further management and treatment.
6. Diabetes: The patient's history of diabetes may require further management and treatment.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia may require further evaluation and treatment.

Plan:

1. Continue tight BP control to prevent further kidney damage.
2. Continue prehydration and mucomyst to prevent further kidney damage.
3. Continue lasix to manage fluid overload.
4. Avoid nephrotoxins and hold lisinopril.
5. Check urine lytes and trend Cr levels.
6. Follow fluid status and exam closely.
7. Continue telemetry and monitor for cardiac arrhythmias.
8. Restart labetelol and continue to hold lisinopril.
9. Resume PT on discharge.
10. Consider restarting lactulose post-cath.

Summary:

The patient is a 24-hour-old ICU admission with a history of cardiac arrhythmias, subdural hemorrhage, and restrictive cardiomyopathy. Over the past 24 hours, the patient's condition has deteriorated, with increasing signs of renal failure, respiratory distress, and cardiovascular instability. Despite aggressive diuretic therapy, the patient's urine output has decreased, and their lactate levels have increased. The patient's cardiac enzymes have remained stable, and their ABG results show good oxygenation and stable pH. The patient's EKG and CXR have also remained unchanged.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Acute Renal Failure (ARF): The patient's increasing signs of renal failure, including decreasing urine output and elevated lactate levels, put them at risk for further deterioration and potential need for renal replacement therapy.
2. Cardiac Instability: The patient's history of cardiac arrhythmias and restrictive cardiomyopathy, combined with their current cardiovascular instability, increase their risk for cardiac arrest and potential need for invasive cardiac monitoring.
3. Respiratory Distress: The patient's increasing respiratory distress, including perioral cyanosis and low oxygen saturation, put them at risk for respiratory failure and potential need for mechanical ventilation.
4. Septic Shock: The patient's elevated lactate levels and worsening renal function increase their risk for septic shock and potential need for vasopressors and other supportive therapies.
5. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of subdural hemorrhage and potential bleeding diathesis increase their risk for gastrointestinal bleeding and potential need for endoscopy and other diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue close monitoring of the patient's cardiovascular and respiratory status, with frequent assessments of their vital signs, cardiac rhythm, and oxygen saturation.
2. Consider further diuretic therapy to manage the patient's fluid overload and potential worsening of their renal function.
3. Consider initiation of vasopressors to support the patient's blood pressure and perfusion.
4. Consider initiation of mechanical ventilation to support the patient's respiratory function.
5. Consider consultation with a cardiologist to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential need for invasive cardiac monitoring.
6. Consider consultation with a nephrologist to further evaluate the patient's renal function and potential need for renal replacement therapy.
7. Continue close monitoring of the patient's gastrointestinal status, with frequent assessments of their stool output and potential need for endoscopy and other diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation. He has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He has also undergone burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma. The patient is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) due to volume overload and acute kidney injury.

The patient's condition has deteriorated over the past 24 hours, with increasing signs of volume overload, including worsening renal function, elevated lactate levels, and decreased urine output. He has been receiving diuretics, including Lasix, but has not responded well to treatment. His blood pressure has been unstable, and he has required frequent boluses of IV fluids.

The patient's cardiac status is also concerning, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 99/67 mmHg. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, and he has been experiencing chest pain.

The patient's laboratory results are concerning, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 29 mg/dL. His electrolyte levels are also abnormal, with a potassium level of 4.4 mEq/L and a magnesium level of 2.1 mg/dL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload is likely contributing to his worsening renal function and decreased urine output. Continued diuresis may be necessary to manage this condition.
2. Acute kidney injury: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his BUN level is also abnormal. This may be due to prerenal failure or acute tubular necrosis.
3. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's cardiac status is concerning, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute and elevated cardiac enzymes. He may be at risk for further cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation.
4. Chest pain: The patient is experiencing chest pain, which may be related to his cardiac status or other underlying conditions.
5. Electrolyte imbalances: The patient's electrolyte levels are abnormal, which may be contributing to his symptoms and worsening renal function.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk for infection, particularly given his recent surgery and prolonged hospitalization.
7. Neurological complications: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma and may be at risk for further neurological complications, including seizures or brain edema.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrest, who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) placement. He also has atrial fibrillation and has undergone burr hole evacuation for a subdural hematoma.

The patient's current condition is complicated by volume overload, likely due to the surgery and the use of Lasix, which was held during the procedure. He has also developed acute on chronic renal failure, with a creatinine level of 1.6 mg/dL. His blood pressure is 99/67 mmHg, and his heart rate is 86 bpm.

The patient's respiratory status is stable, with a SpO2 of 95%. His neurological exam is stable, with no new findings. His laboratory results show elevated lactate levels, with a value of 2.7 mmol/L.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Continue Lasix gtt with a goal of I + O negative 2 L today.
2. Change carvedilol to metoprolol for rate control with less antihypertensive effect and uptitrate as needed.
3. No Coumadin for now, but consider this in 3 weeks after neurosurgical follow-up for neurosurgery.
4. Continue simvastatin and change carvedilol to metoprolol as above.
5. Continue diuresis and trend creatinine.
6. Continue to trend creatinine and [**Hospital1 7**] lytes during diuresis.
7. Continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose.
8. Neuro checks q4 hrs and appreciate neuro sx input.
9. Neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient.
10. Repeat head CT this a.m.

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

1. Worsening of volume overload, leading to further fluid overload and increased risk of cardiac arrest.
2. Progression of acute on chronic renal failure, leading to increased risk of kidney damage and failure.
3. Development of cardiac arrhythmias, such as atrial fibrillation, which can worsen cardiac function and increase the risk of cardiac arrest.
4. Increased risk of respiratory failure due to the patient's chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and sleep apnea.
5. Development of neurological complications, such as seizures or stroke, due to the patient's history of subdural hematoma and burr hole evacuation.
6. Increased risk of infection due to the patient's immunocompromised state and the use of prophylactic antibiotics.
7. Development of electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia, due to the patient's diuretic therapy and electrolyte wasting.
8. Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's use of anticoagulant therapy and the risk of bleeding complications from the burr hole evacuation.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrest, who underwent cardiac bypass surgery and is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) with a diagnosis of systolic heart failure (EF 15%) and atrial fibrillation. He developed volume overload, which was managed with diuretics, but was likely overdiuresed, leading to cold, clammy, and mottled extremities. He received fluid boluses and morphine for respiratory distress and responded well. The patient's electrolytes, renal function, and cardiac enzymes are being closely monitored.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Cardiac Complications:
	* Atrial fibrillation: tachycardia may contribute to poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
	* Coronary artery disease: CAD s/p CABG, with a history of myocardial infarction and cardiac arrest.
2. Renal Complications:
	* Acute on chronic renal failure: creatinine 2.1 today, recent baseline of 1.2, likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed overdiuresis.
	* Urine output: decreased, likely due to overdiuresis and poor cardiac function.
3. Respiratory Complications:
	* Respiratory distress: patient received morphine for agitation and respiratory distress.
	* Pneumonia: CTA anteriorly, mild basilar rales on posterior lung exam.
4. Neurological Complications:
	* Subdural hematoma s/p burrhole/evacuation: neurologic exam stable, but repeat head CT is needed.
	* Sleep apnea: patient is using BiPAP overnight and when napping.
5. Endocrine Complications:
	* Diabetes mellitus: fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
6. Infection Complications:
	* Sepsis: patient has a central line, which is a potential source of infection.
	* VAP: patient has a high risk of developing ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's fluid status and adjust diuretic therapy accordingly.
2. Consider central access to better measure the patient's fluid status.
3. Continue metoprolol for rate control and uptitrate as needed.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac enzymes and troponin levels.
5. Repeat head CT and continue to trend creatinine.
6. Continue to manage the patient's diabetes and adjust insulin dosing as needed.
7. Consider changing Plavix to aspirin (if okay from neurosurgical perspective).
8. Continue simvastatin, metoprolol, and lisinopril.
9. Monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
10. Consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with a history of coronary artery disease, previous myocardial infarction, and cardiac arrhythmia. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator placement. The patient developed atrial fibrillation and was treated with diuretics, which led to overdiuresis and worsening renal function. He was given fluid boluses and morphine for respiratory distress and was stabilized.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Volume Overload: The patient is at risk of developing volume overload due to his history of cardiac disease and previous overdiuresis.
2. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may continue to contribute to his symptoms, including poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, and he may be at risk of developing acute kidney injury or further decline in renal function.
4. Diabetic Ketoacidosis: The patient's blood glucose levels are elevated, and he may be at risk of developing diabetic ketoacidosis.
5. Subdural Hematoma: The patient has a history of subdural hematoma, and there is a risk of further bleeding or complications.
6. Sleep Apnea: The patient has a history of sleep apnea, and there is a risk of respiratory complications.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O.
2. Continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status.
3. Consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of his fluid status.
4. Consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function.
5. Continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed.
6. No Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurgical f/u).
7. Attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation.
8. Continue simvastatin, metoprolol.
9. Trend creatinine and consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve.
10. Continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose.
11. Neuro checks q4 hrs and neurosurg f/u in 12-26 weeks as outpatient.
12. Repeat head CT today.

ICU Care:

1. Nutrition: Continue regular insulin sliding scale.
2. Lines: 20 Gauge - [**2109-2-6**] 07:29 PM.
3. Prophylaxis: DVT - SQ UF Heparin, Stress ulcer - PPI.
4. VAP: Monitor for signs of ventilator-associated pneumonia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) following myocardial infarction (MI) and coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), systolic heart failure (EF 15%) with an implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD), and atrial fibrillation (AF) following burr hole evacuation for subdural hematoma.

The patient was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of acute on chronic renal failure, fluid overload, and atrial fibrillation. The patient's condition has been complicated by overdiuresis, resulting in cold, clammy, mottled extremities, and worsening renal function.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 86 beats per minute, blood pressure of 99/67 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient's cardiac enzymes are stable, and the electrocardiogram (EKG) shows a ventricular-paced rhythm.

The patient's laboratory results show worsening renal function, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL, and an elevated lactate level of 2.7 mmol/L. The patient's blood glucose level is 113 mg/dL, and the patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits.

The patient's medical plan includes:

1. Holding diuretics and fluids to allow for repletion of intravascular volume.
2. Starting digoxin to improve cardiac function and reduce symptoms.
3. Continuing metoprolol to control heart rate and improve cardiac output.
4. Monitoring the patient's fluid and respiratory status closely.
5. Considering central access to better measure the patient's fluid status.
6. Considering a repeat echocardiogram to evaluate cardiac function.
7. Continuing simvastatin, metoprolol, and aspirin for CAD.
8. Holding further diuresis and monitoring the patient's creatinine level.
9. Considering urine lytes if creatinine does not improve.
10. Continuing insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose for DM.
11. Continuing Keppra for total 7 days for subdural hematoma.
12. Repeating head CT today.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Cardiac complications: worsening cardiac function, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest.
2. Renal complications: further worsening of renal function, acute kidney injury, and end-stage renal disease.
3. Respiratory complications: respiratory failure, pneumonia, and acute respiratory distress syndrome.
4. Neurological complications: worsening of subdural hematoma, cerebral edema, and neurological deficits.
5. Infection complications: sepsis, pneumonia, and wound infections.
6. Bleeding complications: bleeding from central access, gastrointestinal bleeding, and intracranial bleeding.

The patient's condition requires close monitoring and management to prevent these complications and improve his clinical status.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old man who has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He has a biventricular pacemaker and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He has also recently undergone subdural hematoma evacuation.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* He has a persistent left subdural extra-axial collection with residual acute hemorrhage, which is not changing on repeat head CT scans.
* He has developed volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but worsened due to hypotension and cool, clammy extremities. He required fluid boluses to correct the volume depletion.
* He is currently receiving CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.
* His mental status is variable, with periods of being lucid and disoriented to place and time.

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (up from 1.2 mg/dL)
* Hemoglobin: 12.2 g/dL
* Platelet count: 254 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 11.7 K/uL
* Serum albumin: 3.8 g/dL
* Serum calcium: 8.9 mg/dL
* Serum magnesium: 2.7 mg/dL
* Serum phosphorus: 5.2 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 0.02 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 2.3 mmol/L

The patient's medications include:

* Metoprolol: 75 mg TID (increased from 50 mg q8)
* Digoxin: 0.125 mg
* Omeprazole: changed to lansoprazole
* Plavix: discontinued
* Simvastatin: continued
* Aspirin: considered (pending neurosurgical input)
* Keppra: continued for 7 days
* Insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale: continued at current dose

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Acute kidney injury (AKI) due to hypotension and fluid overload
* Cardiac arrhythmias (e.g., atrial fibrillation) due to underlying cardiac disease and medications
* Respiratory failure due to sleep apnea and potential pneumonia
* Infection (e.g., ventilator-associated pneumonia) due to prolonged ICU stay
* Gastrointestinal bleeding due to prolonged use of anticoagulation medications
* Worsening of underlying cardiac disease due to stress and hypotension

The patient's treatment plan includes:

* Continuing diuretic therapy with close monitoring of fluid status
* Adjusting medications to control atrial fibrillation and cardiac arrhythmias
* Monitoring for signs of AKI and adjusting fluid management accordingly
* Continuing CPAP for oxygenation and sleep apnea management
* Monitoring for signs of infection and adjusting antibiotics as necessary
* Continuing gastrointestinal prophylaxis with lansoprazole
* Monitoring for signs of worsening cardiac disease and adjusting treatment accordingly

 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - contine digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CTshowed residual acute hemorrhage. Per neurosurgery this
   is resolving and is not contributing to worsening apnea
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: modified diet

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male who has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), has a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%, and has a biventricular pacemaker and implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD). He recently developed a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated via a burr hole.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: He is receiving continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) due to underlying sleep apnea and is requiring oxygenation support.
* Cardiovascular: He has atrial fibrillation, which is contributing to his symptoms and fluid overload. His heart rate is in the 90s, and he is receiving metoprolol for rate control.
* Renal: He has acute renal failure, which is likely prerenal in origin due to poor forward flow and overdiuresis. His creatinine level is 2.1 mg/dL.
* Neurological: His neurological exam is stable, and he is receiving neuro checks every 4 hours.
* Gastrointestinal: He is having difficulty tolerating food and is receiving a modified diet.
* Endocrine: He has diabetes mellitus, and his fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Worsening of his cardiac condition, including further fluid overload and decreased cardiac output.
* Development of respiratory failure, including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
* Progression of his renal failure, including need for dialysis.
* Development of sepsis or other infections, including pneumonia or urinary tract infections.
* Worsening of his neurological condition, including increased intracranial pressure or cerebral edema.
* Development of gastrointestinal complications, including gastrointestinal bleeding or obstruction.

To manage these potential complications, the patient's care team should continue to monitor his fluid and respiratory status, adjust his diuretic and insulin therapy as needed, and consider repeat echocardiograms to evaluate his cardiac function. Additionally, the patient should be closely monitored for signs of infection, and his neurologic status should be regularly assessed.

 RENAL FAILURE, ACUTE (ACUTE RENAL FAILURE, ARF)
 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 72-year-old male who underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) and has a history of cardiac arrest, atrial fibrillation, and subdural hematoma evacuation. He is currently in the intensive care unit (ICU) for management of his condition.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.1°C (96.9°F)
* Heart rate: 108 bpm
* Blood pressure: 119/77 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 36 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 95%
* Heart rhythm: Ventricular paced

The patient's laboratory results show:

* Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 28 mg/dL
* Electrolytes: Na 141 mEq/L, K 4.4 mEq/L, Cl 98 mEq/L, HCO3 28 mEq/L
* Glucose: 60 mg/dL
* White blood cell count (WBC): 11.7 K/uL
* Hemoglobin (Hb): 15.4 g/dL
* Platelet count (Plt): 254 K/uL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Acute renal failure (ARF)
* Cardiomyopathy, restrictive
* Subdural hematoma (SDH)
* Coronary artery disease (CAD) with history of myocardial infarction (MI) and CABG
* Atrial fibrillation
* Sleep apnea

The patient's medications include:

* Metoprolol
* Digoxin
* Omeprazole (changed to lansoprazole)
* Heparin sodium (prophylaxis)
* Dilantin
* Insulin (NPH and Humalog sliding scale)
* Keppra

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continuing to monitor his mental status
* Holding diuretics and fluids at this point and monitoring I/O
* Starting digoxin
* Continuing to monitor fluid and respiratory status
* Considering central access if needed
* Considering repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
* Continuing metoprolol for rate control
* Attempting to touch base with neurosurgery regarding anticoagulation
* Changing Plavix to aspirin if okay from neurosurgical perspective
* Continuing simvastatin and metoprolol
* Trending creatinine and holding further diuresis
* Considering urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
* Continuing insulin NPH and Humalog sliding scale at current dose
* Continuing Keppra for total 7 days
* Repeat head CT today

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Worsening of ARF
* Cardiac arrhythmias
* Respiratory distress
* Sepsis
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Hypoglycemia
* Hyperglycemia
* Infection
* Cardiac tamponade
* Respiratory failure

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his plan of care as needed to prevent these potential complications and ensure his optimal recovery.

The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent cardiac bypass surgery, CABG, and has a history of coronary artery disease, systolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. He developed a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated, and has been admitted to the ICU for management. His current condition is marked by volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but required a fluid bolus to correct hypotension and cool, clammy extremities. He is now receiving CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea.

The patient's laboratory results show acute renal failure with a creatinine level of 2.1, and his cardiac enzymes are elevated. He has a biventricular pacemaker and ICD, and his left ventricular ejection fraction is 15%. His electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation.

Potential medical complications:

1. Volume overload: The patient's volume overload is likely due to poor forward flow and overdiuresis. Further fluid restriction and diuretic hold may be necessary to prevent further volume overload.
2. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, and his cardiac enzymes are elevated, suggesting that his acute renal failure may be due to prerenal factors, such as poor forward flow, and overdiuresis. Further monitoring of his creatinine level and urine output is necessary.
3. Cardiomyopathy: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, and his left ventricular ejection fraction is 15%, suggesting that he may have restrictive cardiomyopathy. Further evaluation with echocardiogram may be necessary to confirm this diagnosis.
4. Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma was evacuated, but he may still be at risk for further bleeding or complications. Close monitoring of his neurologic status and repeat head CT scans may be necessary.
5. Sleep apnea: The patient's sleep apnea may be contributing to his respiratory distress and oxygenation issues. Further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to manage his sleep apnea.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may be contributing to his tachycardia and poor forward flow. Further evaluation and treatment with rate control medications may be necessary.
7. Coronary artery disease: The patient's coronary artery disease may be contributing to his cardiac enzymes and creatinine levels. Further evaluation and treatment may be necessary to manage his coronary artery disease.

Based on the patient's condition, the following plan is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's volume status and adjust diuretic therapy as necessary.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's creatinine level and urine output, and consider further evaluation with urine lytes if necessary.
3. Continue to evaluate the patient's cardiac enzymes and consider further evaluation with echocardiogram if necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's neurologic status and repeat head CT scans as necessary.
5. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's sleep apnea.
6. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's atrial fibrillation.
7. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's coronary artery disease.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent further complications and ensure optimal management of his underlying conditions.

 CARDIOMYOPATHY, RESTRICTIVE
 SUBDURAL HEMORRHAGE (SDH)
   72 year old man s/p CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker
 ICD and
   recent subdural hematoma evacuation developed volume overload which
   responded to initial diuresis, but due to hypotension and cool clammy
   extremities, he required a fluid bolus to correct the volume
   depletion.    He is now improved but requiring CPAP for oyxygenation
   due to underlying sleep apnea.  Will continue to observe his mental
   status.
   72M h/o CAD s/p MI s/p CABG, systolic CHF (EF 15%) s/p ICD, atrial
   fibrillation s/p burr hole/evacuation for subdural hematoma with
   development volume overload clinically although no change on CXR.
   Volume overload likely [**12-25**] IV fluids during surgery in the setting of
   having nodal blocking [**Doctor Last Name **] and lasix held.
   .
   # CHF/Fluid Overload: Likely overdiuresed yesterday morning, as
   evidence by cold, clammy, mottled extremities and bump in creatinine.
   Responded well to fluid boluses as well as morphine for respiratory
   distress.
   - hold diuretics and fluids at this point and monitor I/O
   - start digoxin
   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function
   .
   # Atrial Fibrillation: Tachycardia likely contributing to patient
   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .
   # CORONARIES: CAD s/p CABG. Pt denies any chest pain at this time.
   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .
   #  Acute on Chronic renal failure: Cr 2.1 today, recent baseline of
   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve
   .
   # DM: Fasting hypoglycemia has resolved with decreased insulin dosing.
   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose
   .
   # Subdural Hematoma s/p Burrhole/Evacuation: Neurologic exam stable.
   - neuro checks q4 hrs
   - appreciate neuro sx input
   - neurosurg f/u in [**12-26**] weeks as outpatient
   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
   out after total 10 days
   - repeat head CT today
   .
   # Sleep Apnea: BiBAP overnight and when napping
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Glycemic Control:

   Prophylaxis:

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old male who has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) with a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 15%. He has a history of atrial fibrillation, sleep apnea, and has recently developed a subdural hematoma, which was evacuated via burr hole. He was initially treated with diuresis, but developed volume overload, which responded to fluid boluses. He is currently being treated with digoxin, metoprolol, and simvastatin, and is receiving CPAP for oxygenation due to sleep apnea.

The patient's laboratory results show acute renal failure, with a creatinine level of 2.1 mg/dL, and an elevated troponin level. His cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury. His blood glucose level is 146 mg/dL, and his white blood cell count is 12.2 K/uL.

Potential medical complications:

1. Acute renal failure: The patient's creatinine level is elevated, indicating possible acute renal failure. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent progression to chronic kidney disease.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's cardiac enzymes are elevated, indicating possible cardiac injury. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent cardiac complications.
3. Sleep apnea: The patient's sleep apnea is likely contributing to his respiratory distress. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his sleep apnea.
4. Subdural hematoma: The patient's subdural hematoma is stable, but further monitoring and treatment are necessary to prevent complications.
5. Fluid overload: The patient's fluid overload is likely contributing to his respiratory distress. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his fluid status.
6. Atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is likely contributing to his tachycardia and poor forward flow. Further monitoring and treatment are necessary to manage his atrial fibrillation.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results and adjust treatment as necessary.
2. Continue to manage the patient's fluid status and respiratory distress.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust treatment as necessary.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's sleep apnea and adjust treatment as necessary.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's subdural hematoma and adjust treatment as necessary.
6. Consider repeat head CT to monitor the patient's subdural hematoma.
7. Consider central access if necessary to better monitor the patient's fluid status.
8. Consider repeat echo to evaluate the patient's cardiac function.

Summary:

The patient is a 72-year-old man who underwent CABG, LVEF = 15%, biventricular pacemaker ICD, and recent subdural hematoma evacuation. He developed volume overload, which responded to initial diuresis but worsened due to hypotension and cool, clammy extremities. He received a fluid bolus and is now improved but requires CPAP for oxygenation due to underlying sleep apnea. His mental status is being monitored.

The patient has several ongoing medical issues, including:

1. Renal failure, acute (acute renal failure, ARF): Creatinine is 2.1 today, with a recent baseline of 1.2. The patient is likely experiencing prerenal failure due to poor forward flow and superimposed overdiuresis.
2. Cardiomyopathy, restrictive: The patient has a history of CAD, systolic CHF (EF 15%), and atrial fibrillation. He is being treated with metoprolol for rate control and digoxin.
3. Subdural hematoma s/p burrhole/evacuation: The patient's neurologic exam is stable, and he will continue to receive Keppra for a total of 7 days. Staples will come out after 10 days.
4. Sleep apnea: The patient is receiving BiBAP overnight and when napping.
5. DM: The patient has fasting hypoglycemia, which has resolved with decreased insulin dosing. He will continue to receive insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at the current dose.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Worsening of renal failure: The patient's creatinine is 2.1 today, and he is at risk of further worsening of his renal function.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of CAD, systolic CHF, and atrial fibrillation, which increases his risk of cardiac complications such as arrhythmias, heart failure, and myocardial infarction.
3. Neurologic complications: The patient has a subdural hematoma, which can lead to neurologic complications such as seizures, brain edema, and increased intracranial pressure.
4. Respiratory complications: The patient is receiving CPAP for oxygenation, which increases his risk of respiratory complications such as pneumonia, respiratory failure, and ventilator-associated pneumonia.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections, particularly due to his prolonged ICU stay and invasive lines.

   - continue to monitor fluid and respiratory status
   - consider central access if we feel we need a better measurement of
   his fluid status
   - consider repeat echo to evaluate cardiac function

   symptoms, resulting in poor forward flow and further fluid overload.
   - continue metoprolol for rate control, uptitrate as needed
   - no Coumadin for now; can consider this in 3 weeks (after neurosurg
   f/u)
   - attempt to touch base with neurosurgery re: anticoagulation
   .

   - No apparent h/o PCI, so can change Plavix to aspirin (if okay from
   neurosurgical perspective)
   - continue simvastatin, metoprolol
   .

   1.2. Likely prerenal from poor forward flow with superimposed
   overdiuresis.
   - continue to trend creatinine
   - holding further diuresis, as above
   - consider urine lytes if creatinine does not improve

   - continue insulin NPH + Humalog sliding scale at current dose

   - per neurosurg,  continue Keppra for total 7 days. Staples will come
